p: Regarding the community composition of ECM fungal species based on the tree dataset, the only significant variables were tree species and management type ( Table 3 and Figure 2). The morphometric parameters of trees (height and perimeter) had no effect on the ECM fungal species composition. When the tree species were analyzed separately, only the ECM fungal species compositions of Norway spruce and European larch were affected by the management type ( Table 3 and Figures 3A,B). In Norway spruce trees, C. croceus, Meliniomyces vraolstadiae, P. involutus, T. terrestris, and T. fibrillosa were more abundant in NEX, whereas A. byssoides, L. rufus, and T. asterophora were more abundant in EXT. In European larch trees, C. bataillei, L. laccata, P. olivaceum, and T. terrestris were more abundant in NEX and Suillus spp. in EXT. The ECM fungal species composition of silver birch was not influenced by the studied variables ( Table 3 and Figure 3C). The ECM fungal species composition, based on the root sample dataset, was significantly affected by tree species, management type, and soil horizon ( Table 3 and Figure 4).
